pull.title: Use CScheduler for wallet flushing, remove ThreadFlushWalletDB
pull.body: Also uses std::function instead of boost::function.

repo.name: bitcoin
repo.description: Bitcoin (dont fork from here, fork from bitcoin/bitcoin)

events.body: Concept ACK!. I've considered doing this a few times as well.
Rebased. Note that this now forms the first of a rather long patchset to move wallet callbacks into a background thread without introducing races in APIs or wallet consistency issues.

issue.title: CValidationInterface Cleanups
issue.body: This + #9605 + about three more and wallet updates from blocks will be in a background thread so that they do not block block connection. This PR is just some general cleanup that happened along the way or otherwise makes future changes easier. See commit messages for more details.

events.message: CScheduler boost->std::function, use millisecs for times, not secs
Use CScheduler for wallet flushing, remove ThreadFlushWalletDB
Rename FlushWalletDB -> CompactWalletDB, add function description

issue.title: Replace boost::function with std::function
issue.body:
Fixes: #4323

This logic is cherry-picked from the relevant commit, as referenced here:

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/10395

issue.title: [Wallet][Refactoring] wallet/init refactoring backports
issue.body:
Adapts the following refactoring PRs:

- bitcoin/bitcoin#6961 Constrain constant values to a single location in code
- bitcoin/bitcoin#7576 [Wallet] move wallet help string creation to CWallet
- bitcoin/bitcoin#7577 move "load wallet phase" to CWallet
- bitcoin/bitcoin#7608 Move hardcoded file name out of log messages
- bitcoin/bitcoin#7691 refactor wallet/init interaction
- bitcoin/bitcoin#8776 Wallet refactoring leading up to multiwallet

issue.title: Revamping block validation interface interaction with wallet
issue.body:
Revamped the validation interface interaction with the wallet, encapsulating and improving the mempool and block signaling and each of the wallet signals handler.
Restructured the Sapling witnesses and nullifiers update under the new signals.
Solved several bugs that found on the way as well (Check each commit description).

This PR concludes with #1726 long road :). Pushing our repository around 2 years ahead in btc time in the mempool and validation interface areas (without including RBF). 
The new validation -> wallet interaction architecture will enable further, and much more user facing important, improvements for the syncing process, overall software responsiveness and multithreading locking issues.

Adapted backports:
#6464 --> Always clean up manual transaction prioritization (mempool)
#9240 --> Remove txConflicted (mempool)
#9371 --> Notify on removal (mempool) 
#9605 --> Use CScheduler for wallet flushing, remove ThreadFlushWalletDB (walletdb)
#9725 --> CValidationInterface Cleanups (wallet, validation and validation interface)

comments.body: No, it still must run inside a boost::thread because it relies on boost::interruption_point. I believe @theuni is planning on cleaning that up.

well technically boost::thread takes a boost::function, so I assume if you uses std::bind it would create a boost::function around the std::function......I'll let cory do that when we kill boost::threads.
Yes, I have a local branch with CScheduler converted. I'm doing them in chunks, because the last huge PR proved to be too big to review/rebase. I'll submit that one next (#9566 is the current one).

If you're renaming this function please, finally, change it to something else than FlushWalletDB. What is being done here is not merely a flush (those are done all the time as CWalletDB instances go out of scope) but more like "database consolidation", merging the log files into wallet.dat so that the wallet is self-contained. This has confused many people over time.
